Service Law - Retirement/Superannuation - Retiral benefits - Principle of "no work no pay" - Applicability - Circumstances envisaged - Held, said principle is applicable only to those employees who are not guided by any specific rule relating to absence from duty - Where an employee is prevented by employer from performing his duties, said principle is inapplicable - On facts held, employees including respondents who had moved court of law irrespective of fact whether interim order was passed in their favour or not, shall be entitled to full arrears of salary up to age of 60 yrs - Employees who failed to move any court, and had to retire on attaining age of superannuation, not entitled to arrears of salary - However, they would be treated to have retired at the age of 60 yrs and their retiral benefits shall be re-fixed accordingly A department known as Public Health Engineering Department (PHED) was created during the British period for performing all the works related to public health engineering including sewerage and water supply. Just before Independence , the State of United Provinces (later, State of Uttar Pradesh) created a Local Self-Government Engineering Department (LSGED) which was converted from PHED. All the engineering works of local self-government were entrusted to LSGED. By the Notification dated 18-6-1975 issued under Section 3 of the U.P. Water Supply and Sewerage Act , 1975 (the 1975 Act), the State Government constituted the U.P. Jal Nigam (the Nigam). DAYANAND CHAKRAWARTY 597 conditions which were governing their services prior to such absorption, till the said service conditions were altered/changed by rules/regulations framed in accordance with law. Subsequently, in exercise of the powers conferred under Sections 97(1) and 97(2)(c) of the 1975 Act, and with the previous approval of the State Government , the Nigam made the U.P. Jal Nigam Services of Engineers (Public Health Branch) Regulations, 1978 (the 1978 Regulations) for regulating the recruitment to the posts and the conditions of service of persons appointed to the Jal Nigam Engineers (Public Health Branch). The said 1978 Regulations were made equally applicable to the employees transferred and merged from the erstwhile LSGED and the employees directly recruited by the Nigam and they came into force w.e.f. 27-4-1978. Regulation 31 related to pay, allowance , pension, leave and other conditions of service. There was no separate provision for the age of superannuation of the employees of the Nigam prescribed under the 1978 Regulations. As per Regulation 31, the terms and conditions of service of the employees of the Nigam were to be governed by the same rules, regulations and orders generally applicable to the employees of the State Government and hence the retirement and superannuation age of the employees of the Nigam was stipulated as 58 years in terms of Rule 56(a) of the U.P. Fundamental Rules. Rule 56(a) of the Fundamental Rules was amended vide Notification dated 27-6-2002 and the age of superannuation of the State Government employees was enhanced from 58 years to 60 years which was to come into force on 28-11-2001. However, benefit of such enhancement of age of superannuation was not given to the employees of the Nigam. Writ petitions were preferred by the employees of the Nigam who were being sought to be retired on completing the age of 58 years. The Supreme Court in Harwindra Kumar, (2005) 13 SCC 300 granted the benefit of the Notification dated 27-6-2002 to the petitioners. Thereafter the Nigam framed the U.P. Jal Nigam Employees (Retirement on Attaining Age of Superannuation) Regulations, 2005. By Regulation 3 the retirement age of 60 years was provided for the employees and engineers who were employed in the erstwhile LSGED and who were transferred and merged in the Nigam while Regulation 4, prescribed a separate age of superannuation at the age of 58 years for all other employees who were directly appointed in the Nigam. A number of employees of the Nigam who were affected filed writ petitions challenging the said Regulation 4, which was allowed and the petitioners were allowed to continue in service till the age of 60 years and the said Regulation 4 to the extent it provided the superannuation age of 58 years for employees directly recruited, was declared non est. In an appeal filed thereagainst, the Division Bench of the High Court stayed the declaration but so far as the writ petitioners were concerned, no interim orders were passed and as such, they were allowed to discharge their duties up to the age of 60 years. The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal filed thereagainst relying on its earlier decision rendered in Harwindra Kumar case. Subsequently, the Nigam vide its Resolution dated 13-4-2008 resolved to enhance the age of superannuation of the employees, irrespective of their source of entry , to 60 years and forwarded the same to the Government for approval. However , the State Government refused to accord approval and provided a ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. In the writ petitions filed by the employees of the Nigam challenging the same, the High Court by the impugned judgment declared the 2005 Regulations unconstitutional as it created two classes of employees in determining two separate retirement ages in the absence of any intelligible differentia. Hence , the instant appeal. Dismissing the appeal, the Supreme Court Held: The Supreme Court in Harwindra Kumar case had held that so long as Regulation 31 is not amended, 60 years which is the age of superannuation of the government servants shall be applicable to the employees of the Nigam. However, in contravention of finding of the Supreme Court without amending Regulation 31, new Regulations 3 and 4 of the 2005 Regulations were framed by the Nigam prescribing two separate ages of superannuation for similarly situated employees. Since the creation of the Nigam, irrespective of the source of recruitment, the employees of the Nigam were treated alike for the purpose of superannuation. Subsequently, solely on the basis of source of recruitment no discrimination can be made and differential treatment would not be permissible in the matter of condition of service, including the age of superannuation, in absence of any intelligible differentia distinguishing them from each other. The High Court by the impugned judgment rightly declared the 2005 Regulations unconstitutional and ultra vires Article 14 of the Constitution. (Paras 30, 32 and 34) Prem Chand Somchand Shah v. Union of India, (1991) 2 SCC 48, applied Harwindra Kumar v. Chief Engineer, Karmik, (2005) 13 SCC 300 : 2006 SCC (L&S) 1063, followed Dayanand Chakrawarty v. Chief Engineer, Karmik, 2002 All LJ 1299, cited Furthermore, Regulation 31 of the 1978 Regulations which is a Special Regulation will not be affected by the later Regulation 4 of the 2005 Regulations, in absence of express repeal of the Special Regulation. By implication it cannot be inferred that Regulation 31 stands repealed in view of the subsequent 2005 Regulations (General Regulations). (Para 35) Even if it is treated that both the General Regulation 4 of the 2005 Regulations and Special Regulation 31 of the 1978 Regulations co-exist , one which is advantageous i.e. Regulation 31 shall be applicable to the members of the same service. DAYANAND CHAKRAWARTY 599 The State Government's Order dated 29-6-2009 prescribing a uniform age of superannuation at 58 years for the employees working in the government companies and government corporations cannot prevail over statutory Regulation 31 framed by the Nigam under Section 97(2)(c) of the 1975 Act with the previous approval of the State Government. Therefore, the employees of the Nigam shall not be guided by the State Government's Order dated 29-6-2009 but will continue in the services up to the age of 60 years, in view of Regulation 31, having not yet amended or repealed. Furthermore, in Harwindra Kumar case the Supreme Court has already held that it is not possible for the Nigam to take an administrative decision pursuant to the direction of the State Government in the matter of policy issued under Section 89 of the 1975 Act and direct that the age of superannuation of 60 years applicable to the government servants shall not be applicable to the employees of the Nigam. In view of such finding the Nigam cannot act on the basis of the State Government's Order dated 29-6-2009 providing a uniform age of superannuation at 58 years. (Paras 37 and 38) Harwindra Kumar v. Chief Engineer, Karmik, (2005) 13 SCC 300 : 2006 SCC (L&S) 1063, followed As far as consequential benefits to which the respondents are entitled are concerned, the High Court en-ed in determining back wages of the respondents restricting it to be 20% of the basic salary. The principle of "no work no pay" is not applicable to the employees who were guided by specific rules like Leave Rules, etc. relating to absence from duty. Such principle can be applied to only those employees who were not guided by any specific rule relating to absence from duty. If an employee is prevented by the employer from performing his duties, the employee cannot be blamed for having not worked, and the principle of "no work no pay" shall not be applicable to such employee. In view of the finding that Regulation 31 shall be applicable and the age of superannuation of employees of the Nigam shall be 60 years, the employees including the respondents who moved a court of law in-espective of the fact whether interim order was passed in their favour or not, shall be entitled to full aiTears of salary up to the age of 60 years. The employees, who never moved any court of law and had to retire on attaining the age of superannuation, shall not be entitled for aITears of salary. However, in view of Regulation 31 they will deem to have continued in service up to the age of 60 years. In their case, the appellants shall treat the age of superannuation as 60 years, and re-fix their retiral benefits accordingly. (Paras 48 and 49) Harwindra Kumar V. MUKHOPADHAYA, J.- These Appeals Nos. 5527-28 of 2012 and 5617-59 of 2012 [arising out of SLPs (C) Nos. 31279, 35579 of 2010 and 5218-60 of 2011] have been preferred by the State of Uttar Pradesh and others against the common judgment dated 29-7-2010 passed by the Division Bench of the High Court of Judicature of Allahabad, Lucknow Bench, Lucknow in Dayanand Chakrawarty v. State of V.P 1 whereby the High Court declared the Uttar Pradesh Jal Nigam Employees (Retirement on Attaining Age of Superannuation) Regulations, 2005 which have created two separate ages of retirement amongst same classes of employees, discriminatory and unconstitutional and held that the employees of the Jal Nigam are entitled to continue in service up to the age of 60 years with further directions to pay 20% of back wages to those writ petitioners who in the meantime were forced to retire on attaining the age of 58 years in the absence of any interim order in their cases. The benefit of enhancement of age was confined to the persons who had filed the writ petitions before their retirement and was not granted to those who in the meantime retired at the age of 58 years and had not moved before the High Court. 1 (2010) 6 All LJ 1 C d e f g h ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Before the High Court Writ Petition No. 1191 (SB) of 2009 was filed by the U.P. Engineers Association, Jal Nigam, praying therein to declare the U.P. Jal Nigam Karamchari (Adhivarshita Par Seva Nivarti) Viniyamawali, 2005 [U.P. Jal Nigam Employees (Retirement on Attaining Age of b Superannuation) Regulations, 2005] (hereinafter referred to as "the 2005 Regulations") unconstitutional and ultra vires to the provisions of the Constitution of India and further to quash the orders dated 3-7-2009 and 29-6-2009 passed by Respondents 1 and 2 to the writ petition, respectively. The other prayers were to restrain the respondents from causing retirement of the members of the writ petitioners' Association at the age of 58 years as well c as to allow them to continue to work till they attain the age of 60 years. d e f g 4. Except the aforesaid writ petition, in all other writ petitions, the writ petitioners have challenged their respective order(s) whereby they had been asked to retire on attaining the age of 58 years as per the provisions of the 2005 Regulations. 5. The questions involved in these appeals are: 5.1. Whether two different ages of superannuation of 58 and 60 years can be prescribed for the employees similarly situated, including members of the same service, solely on the basis of their source of entry in the service. 5.2. Whether the Uttar Pradesh Jal Nigam (Retirement on Attaining Age of Superannuation) Regulations, 2005 fixing two different ages of superannuation for similarly situated employees of Jal Nigam are discriminatory and ultra vires under Article 14 of the Constitution of India. 6. The factual matrix of the case is as follows: a department, known as the Public Health Engineering Department (hereinafter referred to as "PHED") was created during the British period for performing all the works related to public health engineering including sewerage and water supply. Just before the Independence, the State of United Province created a Local Self-Government Engineering Department (hereinafter referred to as "LsGED") which was converted from PHED. All the engineering works of Local Self-Government were entrusted to the said newly created Department. 7. Section 37(1) of the 1975 Act provided that the services of the employees and engineers of the Local a Self-Government Engineering Department (LSGED) will be transferred and merged into the newly created Nigam on the same terms and conditions, which were governing their services prior to such absorption, till the said service conditions are altered/changed by the rules or regulations framed in accordance with law. 8. In its second meeting dated 4-4-1977 vide Agenda Item 2.21 the Board b of Nigam resolved that all the provisions of Financial Handbook, Manual of Government Order, Civil Services Regulations, Government Servant Rules and other government orders shall be applicable to the employees of the Nigam, provided the Nigam has not passed any other order. 9. Initially, in exercise of the powers conferred under sub-section (1) and clause (c) of sub-section (2) of Section 97 of the 1975 Act and with the C previous approval of the State Government, the Nigam made regulations for regulating the recruitment to the posts and the conditions of service of the persons appointed to the Uttar Pradesh Jal Nigam Service of Engineers (Public Health Branch) known as "the Uttar Pradesh Service of Engineers (Public Health Branch) Regulations, 1977". 10. Subsequently, in exercise of the powers conferred under sub-section d (1) and clause (c) of sub-section (2) of Section 97 of the 1975 Act, and with the previous approval of the State Government, the Nigam made the Uttar Pradesh Jal Nigam Services of Engineers (Public Health Branch) Regulations, 1978 (hereinafter referred to as "the 1978 Regulations") for regulating the recruitment to the posts and the conditions of service of persons appointed to the Jal Nigam Engineers (Public Health Branch). The e said 1978 Regulations were made equally applicable to the employees transferred and merged from the erstwhile LsGED and the employees directly recruited by the Nigam and it came into force w.e.f. 27-4-1978. Regulation 31 relates to pay, allowance, pension, leave and other conditions of service which reads as follows: "31. Except as provided in these Regulations the pay, allowance, pension, leave, imposition of penalties and other conditions of service of the members of the service shall be regulated by rules, regulations or orders applicable generally to the government service in connection with the affairs of the State." f 11. There is no separate provision for the age of superannuation of employees of the Nigam prescribed under the 1978 Regulations. As per g Regulation 31, the terms and conditions of service of the employees of the Nigam shall be governed by the same rules, regulations and orders generally applicable to the employees of the State Government and hence the retirement and superannuation age of employees of the Nigam shall stand governed by the provisions of Rule 56(a) of the Uttar Pradesh Fundamental Rules contained in the Financial Handbook, Vol. II, Parts II-IV, which reads h as follows: ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. (a) Except as otherwise provided in other clauses of this Rule every government servant shall retire from service on the afternoon of the last day of the month in which he attains the age of fifty-eight years. He may be retained in service after the date of retirement on superannuation with the sanction of the Government on public grounds which must be recorded in writing but he must not be retained after the age of sixty years except in very special circumstances.'' 12. The age of retirement of the State Government employees as per Rule 56(a) of the Uttar Pradesh Fundamental Rules was 58 years. In the year 2001, the State Government vide its Official Order No. 1098/A-1/2001 dated 28-11-2001 informed of its intention to amend clause (a) of Rule 56. Consequently, Rule 56(a) was amended by "the Uttar Pradesh Fundamental (Amendment) Rules, 2002" vide Notification dated 27-6-2002, which came into force on 28-11-2001. As per the amended clause (c) of Rule 56, the age of superannuation of the State Government employees was enhanced from 58 years to 60 years, which reads as follows: "56. (a) Except as otherwise provided in this Rule, every government servant shall retire from service on the afternoon of the last day of the month in which he attains the age of sixty years: Provided that a government servant, whose date of birth is the first day of a month, shall retire from service on the afternoon of the last day of the preceding month on attaining the age of sixty years: Provided further that a government servant, who has attained the age of fifty-eight years on or before the first day of November, 2001 and is on extension in service, shall retire from service on expiry of his extended period of service." 13. In Prem Chand Somchand Shah v. Union of India 12 this Court held: (SCC p. 56, para 8) "8. As regards the right to equality guaranteed under Article 14 the position is well settled that the said right ensures equality amongst equals and its aim is to protect persons similarly placed against discriminatory b treatment. It means that all persons similarly circumstanced shall be treated alike both in privileges conferred and liabilities imposed. Conversely discrimination may result if persons dissimilarly situate are treated equally. Even amongst persons similarly situate differential treatment would be permissible between one class and the other. In that event it is necessary that the differential treatment should be founded on c an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question." 32. Since creation of the Nigam, irrespective of source of recruitment, the employees of the Nigam were treated alike for the purpose of superannuation d and were allowed to superannuate at the age of 58 years as is evident from Regulation 31. 33. As per the decision of this Court in Prem Chand Somchand Shah 12 even amongst persons similarly situated differential treatment would be permissible between one class and the other. In that event it is necessary that e the differential treatment should be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute. So, on the basis of no pay no work, they will not be entitled for arrears. However, their back wages will be restricted @ 20% of the basic salary as per the ratio laid down in G. Vallikumari v. Andhra Education Society 13. Lastly, it is clarified that the extended service will be counted for all the purpose to the abovementioned employees. The petitions are allowed. No costs." 45. We observe that the principle of a "no pay no work" is not applicable to the employees who were guided by specific rules like Leave Rules, etc. relating to absence from duty. Such principle can be applied to only those employees who were not guided by any specific rule relating to absence from duty. If an employee is prevented by the employer from performing his duties, the employee cannot be blamed for having not worked, and the principle of "no pay no work" shall not be b applicable to such employee. 49. The employees including the respondents who moved before a court of law irrespective of the fact whether interim order was passed in their favour or not, shall be entitled for full salary up to the age of 60 years. The arrears of salary shall be paid to them after adjusting the amount if any paid. 49.2. The employees, who never moved before any court of law and had d to retire on attaining the age of superannuation, they shall not be entitled for arrears of salary. However, in view of Regulation 31 they will deem to have continued in service up to the age of 60 years. In their case, the appellants shall treat the age of superannuation at 60 years, fix the pay accordingly and re-fix the retirement benefits like pension, gratuity, etc. On such calculation, e they shall be entitled for arrears of retirement benefits after adjusting the amount already paid. 49.3.
